Brief correction to start: the heart is normally on the left side of the chest. A very small number of people (e.g., dextrocardia/situs inversus) have it on the right. So your client instructions should say “left” unless a client has been medically told otherwise.

Below are clear, client-facing instructions you can use or adapt.

Short, plain-language version for emails / handouts
- Most people’s heart is on the left side of the chest. To monitor heart rate, use a wearable (watch or chest-strap) or check your pulse at the wrist or neck. If you have been told by a doctor that your heart is on the right (dextrocardia), put your hand on the right instead. Stop exercise and seek help if you feel chest pain, fainting, severe shortness of breath, or unusual dizziness.

Step-by-step: easiest and most reliable options
1. Wear a heart-rate monitor (preferred during exercise)
   - Use a chest strap or a wristwatch with continuous heart-rate tracking. Chest straps are most accurate during activity.

2. Manual pulse — radial (wrist) method
   - Stop briefly or slow down so you can count comfortably.
   - Use your index and middle fingers (not your thumb) and place them on the thumb side of the opposite wrist, just below the base of the thumb.
   - Count beats for 15 seconds and multiply by 4 (or count for 30 seconds and multiply by 2).
   - This gives beats per minute (bpm).

3. Manual pulse — carotid (neck) method
   - Place index and middle fingers gently in the groove beside your windpipe.
   - Count for 15 seconds and multiply by 4.
   - Do not press hard and do not check both sides at once.

4. Feeling the heartbeat on the chest
   - If you want to feel the heartbeat, place your hand over the left mid-chest (left side of sternum, around nipple line) — this is where the heartbeat is usually strongest. If your doctor has told you your heart is on the right, place your hand on the right side instead.
   - Note: chest feel can be faint, and wearable monitors or pulse checks are more reliable.

Target heart-rate guidance (quick reference)
- Estimated max HR = 220 − age (rough estimate).
- Moderate intensity: ~50–70% of max HR.
- Vigorous intensity: ~70–85% of max HR.
(Example: age 40 → max ≈180 bpm → moderate 90–126 bpm, vigorous 126–153 bpm.)

Safety and medical advice
- If you have known heart disease, take medications that affect heart rate, or have been advised by a clinician, check with your doctor for a personalized target range before exercising.
- Stop and seek medical care for chest pain, severe shortness of breath, dizziness, fainting, or palpitations that don’t resolve.
